byline.contributor: Mujib Mashal and Joseph Goldstein reported from Kabul, and Jawad Sukhanyar from Jowzjan, Balkh and Baghlan Provinces.
byline.original: By MUJIB MASHAL, JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

abstract: Afghan government has resorted to forming local militias and courting assistance from old warlords as it seeks to beat back fierce Taliban offensive in northern Afghanistan; strategy raises anxieties related to nation's history of civil strife, and directly undermines assurances that security forces have been holding their own against Taliban.
lead_paragraph: The Afghan army is struggling to ward off Taliban offensives, stoking anxieties of factional rivalries in a nation still haunted by a civil war.

headline.main: Afghans Form Militias and Call on Warlords to Battle Taliban
headline.print_headline: Afghans Forming Militias to Fight Against Taliban
